channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Aid Convoy Enters Madaya, a Besieged Syrian Town
item.description: Shipments of food and medical supplies inched toward four besieged settlements amid an international outcry over the rising number of malnutrition deaths.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Princess Cristina of Spain Stands Trial in Tax Fraud Case
item.description: Cristina, the sister of King Felipe VI, is the first member of Spain’s royal family to stand trial, in a case that has become a major embarrassment for the Spanish monarchy.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Head of Poland’s Governing Party Leads a Shift Rightward
item.description: Jaroslaw Kaczynski holds no elective office, but as leader of the governing Law and Justice Party he is the primary force in a rightist consolidation of authority.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Jaroslaw Kaczynski, the leader of the ruling Law and Justice Party in Poland, at a parliamentary session in December. Under Mr. Kaczynski, the party has steered Poland away from its previously Euro-enthusiastic and more liberal stances.

item.title: News Analysis: Catalan Independence Bid Looms Over Spain’s Coalition Efforts
item.description: Catalonia’s status will be impossible for the leaders of the country’s main parties to avoid in determining what kind of government will emerge.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: The newly elected Catalan leader, Carles Puigdemont, center right, embraced his predecessor, Artur Mas, at the regional parliament in Barcelona on Sunday. Mr. Puigdemont vowed to stay on course and break from Spain.

item.title: Mass Party Defections Upend Tunisia Politics
item.description: The Islamist party Ennahda is the dominant faction again after the president’s secular party lost members who protested his son’s post as party chief.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL and FARAH SAMTI
item.media:description: Mohsen Marzouk, the former secretary general of the Nidaa Tounes party, spoke at a rally in Tunis on Sunday. He said he was among the leaders who resigned because the party had lost sight of its vision to build a democratic, modern and secular state.

item.title: An Uncertain New Chapter in Sinaloa, Home State of ‘El Chapo’
item.description: To many residents in Sinaloa, where Joaquín Guzmán Loera was captured, he was and remains El Señor (the Lord), a mythical figure who inspires as much respect as fear.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS and ALBERTO ARCE
item.media:description: Officers kept watch outside the house where the Mexican drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as El Chapo, was captured in Los Mochis, Mexico on Friday.

item.title: News Analysis: Theatrics Surrounding El Chapo’s Capture Distract From Mexico’s Real Woes
item.description: The revelation that Sean Penn interviewed the fugitive drug trafficker gave some Mexicans further justification for their abiding cynicism toward government.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: On the run, Joaquín Guzmán Loera hoped to make a movie, but his plan led to his capture, officials said.

item.title: Diplomats Meet in Pakistan in Effort to Restart Peace Talks With Taliban
item.description: In Islamabad, representatives of the United States, China, Pakistan and Afghanistan met to try to lay the groundwork for talks with the insurgents.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Afghan security forces checked travelers in northeastern Afghanistan, near the Pakistan border, on Sunday. Peace talks with the Taliban have become more urgent as the insurgents continue to seize Afghan territory.

item.title: Video of El Chapo Raid Shows Volley of Gunfire
item.description: Video obtained by a Mexican media network shows marines throwing grenades and firing dozens of shots into the hide-out of the drug kingpin known as El Chapo.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR
item.media:description: A video obtained by Televisa, a Mexican television network, showed members of Mexico’s military storming the hide-out of Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the drug kingpin known as El Chapo.

item.title: World Briefing: Teenager Attacks Jewish Teacher in Marseille With a Machete
item.description: The teenager told the French police that he had carried out the attack in the name of God and the Islamic State, according to the Marseille prosecutor.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: A soldier at a Jewish school in Marseille, France, on Monday after a teenager attacked a Jewish teacher.

item.title: Israeli Police Investigate B’Tselem Office Fire
item.description: No one was hurt in the fire at the offices of the Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories, which has been at the center of a political dispute.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Top Suspect in Paris Attacks Had Traveled to Britain, Officials Say
item.description: Abdelhamid Abaaoud had visited Britain despite being named in an international arrest warrant for a foiled plot, and appeared to have taken pictures of London landmarks, officials said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Abdelhamid Abaaoud, who is believed to be the coordinator of the November terrorist attacks in Paris.

item.title: ISIS Attack on Baghdad Mall Kills 17
item.description: A gun battle raged for nearly two hours in the Iraqi capital, but most of the casualties were caused by a car bomb and two suicide bombers.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Letter From Europe: For French Ski Resorts, a Scramble to Offset Snow Deficit
item.description: Given the importance of winter tourism, resorts are trying to keep visitors entertained in a world where they can always just hop a flight to a beach.
item.category: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:description: Practicing grass skiing at a resort in the Italian Alps last month.

item.title: Global Health: Progress in Jimmy Carter’s Quest to End Guinea Worm Disease
item.description: Only 22 cases of the disease were reported in 2015, a significant drop from the 126 cases reported in 2014.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Guinea worm inside a container at The Carter Center’s office in Nigeria. Only 22 cases of the disease were reported in 2015, the center said.

item.title: Fire at Rights Group’s Offices Was Not Arson, Israeli Investigators Say
item.description: An electrical short-circuit caused the fire at B’Tselem, a group that monitors the treatment of Palestinians, officials said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: An entrance to the offices of B’Tselem, an Israeli human rights group, on Monday after a fire.

item.title: Swedish Police, Accused of Cover-Up, Look Into Reports of Sexual Assault at Festival
item.description: The authorities said they were investigating why the public had not been informed about the attacks by men said to be migrants in Stockholm last summer.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Revolt Network Foments New Brand of Jewish Terror in Israel
item.description: Israel’s domestic security agency sees a group of young extremists from settlement outposts as being behind a wave of violence against Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yisrael Ben-Shlomo at his sheep pen in the West Bank. He described Mordechai Meyer, 18, as “a good and wholesome kid,” but Israel’s domestic security agency says Mr. Meyer belongs to a Jewish terror network.

item.title: Qapqal County Journal: Manchu, Former Empire’s Language, Hangs On at China’s Edge
item.description: Descendants of the settlers, who embarked in 1764 on a trek that took them from the northeast to the west, struggle to keep a nearly vanished tongue alive.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Xibe farmworkers in a cotton field near Qapqal County, China, in October.

item.title: Tributes to David Bowie in the Place Where It All Started
item.description: Fans left flowers and a candle at a mural of Ziggy Stardust, one of the rock star’s alter egos, in the neighborhood where he was born in south London.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and MADELEINE KRUHLY
item.media:description: A fan took a photo of a mural of David Bowie in Brixton, the London neighborhood where he was born, on Monday.
